entry.title: SAP Enable now - Structure for Authors
entry.content:
Dear Team,

Uncertain which forum to post this question in, but here goes.

Best practice and in my own experience, the suggestion has always been to create "Author" folders in the Workspace in Manager/Producer in the event that multiple authors will be recording simulations and creating work books or group.s My understanding is the grouping by Author is related to the write tokens in the development process.

Usually, I create Author folders and within those folders I structure the Books and groups by Business Processes per module. Then, once the courses are finished and finalised, I move it to a Publish folder where the final courses will be Scormed and shared to LMS.

What would the impact be if Author folders are not created for the development phase, but only the SAP Business Process Structure with an author per module/stream? How would this impact the write tokens? I have a client who doesn't understand the purpose of structuing the development folders by Authors first and would like to define with clarity the purpose for doing so.

entry.title: Re: EWM PPF Action - Where can I execute custom ABAP code...
entry.content:
Hi Daniil,
we want to send an idoc to an external sub system when a warehouse task is confirmed. 

SAP Standard WHO PPF is designed for actions that trigger the printing of various documents, labels, or forms. When we create a customer-specific action definition, we still need a printer and a spool parameter. As far as I understand, the condition table cannot be adjusted in such a way that we do not need this. Without a condition record, we cannot trigger the PPF via the standard application PWO / Maintenance Group PWO.

Or what do you think?

entry.title: What's New in SAP Asset Performance Management 2508
entry.content:
In this release, we‚Äôre rolling out a new set of features in SAP Asset Performance Management that make industrial system setup, monitoring, and device management even more efficient. From building and editing industrial system templates directly in Excel, cutting down on unnecessary alerts with advanced rule execution modes, and new embedded IoT capabilities, these updates are designed to save time, reduce errors, and give you more control over complex operations.

Let's dive right in.

New Excel import/export features for industrial system templates

In the Manage Industrial System Template app, you can now use Excel to import/export system templates and template structures to streamline hierarchy management and reduce manual work.

From the Industrial System Template list page, the system now provides a downloadable Excel template that simplifies the process of creating a new system template. It includes:

  • Overview, list of fields, and system template header details
  • Top node, aspect hierarchy, relationships, and attributes

You can then make edits in Excel and re-import the file to create a new industrial system. For more information, see Creating an Industrial System Template through Import.

From the industrial system template object page (tab Structure) choose Import or Export System Template Structure to:

  • Export system template structures for review or changes
  • Import system template structures to build or expand elements
  • Add new system elements directly via Excel

All imports run as background jobs, avoiding workflow interruptions

Business benefits:

  • Faster hierarchy setup and updates
  • Reduced risk of data entry errors
  • Easier collaboration through shareable Excel files
  • Significant time savings for reliability engineers

For more information, refer to Export or Import a System Structure Template.

 

Enhancing Functional System Elements with Failure Data Profiles and Functional Failures

For functions in an industrial system, you can now add additional attributes, including failure data profiles and functional failures to functional system elements in industrial systems and industrial system templates.

By doing so, you get deeper insights into system performance and failure patterns. This enables more proactive maintenance strategies, reducing downtime and optimizing resource allocation for enhanced operational efficiency.

For more information, see 

  • Adding an Additional Attribute (industrial system templates)
  • Adding an Additional Attribute (industrial system)

 

New embedded IoT features in Manage Devices app (part of Early Adopter Care program)

The following new capabilities are now available for you to explore via the Manage Devices app in SAP Asset Performance Management, as part of the Early Adopter Care program:

  • Perform administrator tasks like managing data broker settings and checking audit logs.
  • Connect device through OPC UA support
  • Explore the available micro services that are included for more flexibility.
  • Consume third-party IoT platform provider APIs.

Authenticate devices using Certificates.

For more information, see Getting Early Adopter Access to New Features and Functions.

Watch this space for a dedicated blog - coming soon! 

Trigger rule action after multiple violations only

You can now define sophisticated rules that delay immediate actions, ensuring that transient issues don't trigger unnecessary alerts. This feature enhances system monitoring capabilities by introducing two innovative modes: Consecutive Condition Fulfilment Mode and Duration Mode.

New Modes for Condition Monitoring

  1. Consecutive Condition Fulfilment Mode: In this mode, actions are triggered only after a condition is met consecutively a specified number of times. This helps ensure that only persistent issues, rather than one-off anomalies, are flagged for attention.

  2. Duration Mode: This mode allows actions to be triggered when conditions are met within a specific time interval, regardless of the order. By using a characteristic to determine the time frame, engineers can tailor monitoring to better capture intermittent issues that persist over defined periods.

Business Benefits

By implementing these advanced rule definitions, businesses can significantly reduce false alarms and improve focus on genuine system issues thereby optimizing both time and costs.

For more information, see Triggering a Rule.

Automatic Refresh of Alerts List

To ensure you stay updated with the latest alerts without needing to refresh manually, automatic refresh ON toggle is enabled by default. Alerts are updated every 60 seconds. You can disable the toggle if you want to refresh the alerts list manually.

Sort, group & search options in Communication System filters

You can now effortlessly sort, group, and search for values across different tabs using enhanced filter functionality. For example, with technical objects, the default sorting is based on category, and you have the flexibility to search, sort, or group by category, technical object type, or active/inactive status. This unified approach to filtering streamlines data management and ensures ease of navigation regardless of the tab you're working in. For more information, see Communication Systems.

Stay Informed and Get Involved

  • For an exhaustive list of all new features, visit the SAP Help Portal - What's New in SAP Asset Performance Management.. 
  • Submit or vote for the improvement you would like to see in the SAP Continuous Influence session.

See you soon for the 2509 update! 

 

 

‚ÄÉ

entry.title: Re: Situation Handling: Error during related app Navigation
entry.content:
Hello,

A few things..

1. Ensure the navigation action has the same sematic object and action as the Fiori App you are trying to navigate to. You can use /n/ui2/flpcm_cust to view these details for the App. Or you can reference the Fiori Apps Library, search for your app, go to the 'Implementation Information' tab and view the Target Mapping section. This will have the Semantic Object and Action.

2. Ensure your parameter values are being passed to the app from either your anchor or trigger object. The parameter values can be found in the same target mapping section above. 

3. SU53 - If you do not have access the necessary catalog or app, it will tell you here

Thanks,
Jared

entry.title: Re: Caculate POC of wbs base on POC of activity in SAP PS
entry.content:
Your mistake is precisely in the choice of method "ESTIMATION".

The "ESTIMATION" method in SAP Progress Analysis is a subjective, schedule-based technique used to assess the Percentage of Completion (POC) for project activities or WBS elements when no more objective measurement is available.

In this case, you manually maintain the planned or actual POC for each activity or WBS element for each period. SAP prescribes the periods based on the dates you enter for the work packages.

Typical Steps:

  1. Assign the "Estimation" method to your WBS/activities.
  2. Maintain planned and actual POC manually, as progress is assessed for each period.
  3. SAP records your entered (cumulative) POC for each object.
  4. The system calculates project progress based on your inputs, which can then be rolled up if aggregation settings are configured.

Regards

entry.title: Re: Optimizing Data Movement in SAP Datasphere: Replication Flow or Remote Table Replication?
entry.content:
@paddyw Yes ‚Äî when you use Replication Flow in SAP Datasphere with a database table as the source (for example from SAP HANA Cloud, ABAP-based systems like S/4HANA or ECC, or supported DB connectors), a database trigger (or equivalent change tracking mechanism) is typically created on the source system to capture changes.
Just to Note:

  • If you configure replication in ‚ÄúInitial Load only‚Äù mode, then triggers are not kept, since there‚Äôs no ongoing delta capture.

  • If you configure ‚ÄúInitial + Delta‚Äù, then yes, triggers (or equivalent) will be created and maintained until replication is stopped.

entry.title: Protecting Privileged Information in ITSM and CCM
entry.content:
We occasionally have users include privileged information (e.g., passwords, keys) in plain text in ITSM or CCM documents/transactions. Obviously (to me, at least), they shouldn't do that. I had a user ask if there is a way to secure such information in an ITSM or CCM document. As far as I know, there isn't anyway to do so. A couple of options I did suggest were to provide the information directly to the support team, or to attach a password-protected/encrypted document.

Does anyone know of a way to secure privileged information in an ITSM or CCM document?

entry.title: Re: Error "Missing Customizing in table TFK028G (CAMT053...
entry.content:
Hi Jochem,

as we discussed the key is to 'Assign External Transaction Types to Posting Rules' with the respective sign -/+ in the customizing for the electronic account statement (V_T028G). After that you should maintain the missing entry in 'Define Transactions for Electronic Bank Statement Transfer', which are used in transaction FPB7.

Kind Regards,

Tobias

entry.title: Re: Change existing ANID to New ANID after registration o...
entry.content:
https://connectsupport.ariba.com/sites#item-view&/KB0990626

It is not possible to manually change or add a ANID as NetworkId.

When you send supplier registration invitation, supplier user creates a new account on Business Network or login using an existing account. This is the process when the ANID is associated to supplier as a NetworkId in Ariba Strategic Sourcing.

The "workaround" to do it is to unlink the public supplier user and ANID first and then, inviting the supplier again so that they will be able to link (login with the correct existing account) the ANID as required.

This article will help you: https://me.sap.com/notes/KB0395564

entry.title: Integrated Enterprise Planning: How SAP SAC and SAP IBP Create Optimal, Executable Plans Together
entry.content:
The Business Scenario: BestRun Bikes

Our starting point is the fictional bicycle company "BestRun Bikes" with global distribution of mountain bikes, cruise bikes, and e-bikes. The analysis reveals an interesting market gap: While e-bikes are very successful in the USA, they are completely missing from the German portfolio. This is exactly where our integrated planning approach comes in.

Technical Architecture: The Best of Both Worlds

SAP Analytics Cloud: Finance & Controlling Excellence

  • Target Setting with dynamic planning functions
  • Seasonality Transfer between markets via Deep Copy
  • Gross Margin Calculation with S/4HANA integration
  • Financial Consolidation down to P&L level

SAP Integrated Business Planning: Supply Chain Optimization

  • Demand Planning with constraint-based algorithms
  • Supply Planning with multi-scenario optimization
  • Capacity Planning across network topologies
  • Decision Assistance for scenario evaluation

Integration: Bidirectional Connection between IBP and SAC

The key lies in the built-in bidirectional data integration between SAC and IBP. This enables movement data and master data management and provides automated transfer of planning targets (Demand) and validated capacity plans (Supply) and consensus with financial planning and controlling ‚Äì without manual interface programming.

Process idea Step-by-Step

Step 1: Baseline Analysis (SAC)

Dashboard: Company Current State

- Gross Revenue by Product: Mountain Bikes, Cruise Bikes, Commuter eBikes

- Geographic Split: Germany vs. USA

- Identification: Germany = 0 eBike Revenue

 

Step 2: Target Setting (SAC)

Planning Model: Revenue Target Setting

- New Estimate: 350 Million EUR for eBikes Germany

- Seasonality Transfer: USA ‚Üí Germany (Deep Copy, including seasonalities, with shifts if needed)

- Distribution and Allocation Logic: Proportional with Distribute function

- Automatic Gross Margin Calculation in SAP Analytics Cloud

 

 

Step 3: Integrated Connection from SAC to IBP

Integration Layer: SAC ‚Üí IBP

- Automated Data Management in SAC

- Target Values ‚Üí Demand Planning Module

- Refresh of IBP Planning Workspaces

 

 

Step 4: Supply Optimization (IBP)

Decision Assistance Scenarios:

- Base Version/Extra Shift: 98.46M Gross Profit

- Base Version/Capacity Reallocation: 100.92M Gross Profit 

- Base Version/Delayed Production: 98.38M Gross Profit

- Contract Manufacturing Evaluation

 

Step 5: Validated Plan Return (Data Management)

Integration Layer: IBP ‚Üí SAC

- Optimized Capacity Plan ‚Üí Current Plan Promotion

- Automated Variance Calculation (Œî = 0 after Promotion)

- Finance Current Plan Update for P&L Integration

 

Step 6: Advanced Analytics: Monte Carlo Simulation with SAP Analytics Cloud Compass

A highlight of the solution is the risk-based plan validation through SAP Analytics Cloud Compass:

 

Driver Model Definition

Critical Planning Drivers for the SAC Planning Model:

- Sales Volumes (Volume Driver)

- Prices (Price Driver)

- Capacity Utilization (Capacity Utilization)

- Material Costs (Material Cost Driver)

- Logistics Costs (Logistics Cost Driver)

Simulation Configuration

Monte Carlo Parameters:

- Iterations: 10,000 scenarios

- Driver Variations: Realistic ranges

- Output Target: Operating Result

Simulation Results:

- Realistic Case: 90% probability for 84,000-118,000 USD

- Pessimistic Case: 67,024 USD (5% quantile)

- Optimistic Case: 135,470 USD (95% quantile)

 

Quantified Benefits

  • Planning Time: Drastic reduction through better integration of sub-plans and LoBs
  • Planning Quality: Understanding success probability instead of "gut feeling"
  • Integration: One system, one truth instead of Excel loops
  • Agility: Real-time scenario updates instead of static plans

Eliminated Pain Points

  • Manual coordination between departments
  • Excel-based planning loops
  • Plans without feasibility checks
  • Risk assessment based on assumptions

Conclusion

The combination of SAP Analytics Cloud and SAP Integrated Business Planning impressively demonstrates what modern enterprise planning can look like: Integrated, automated, and risk-validated.

Instead of isolated tool landscapes, a coherent planning ecosystem emerges that connects strategic ambitions with operational feasibility.

entry.title: Suggestion required for implementing DPC (Dynamic Period Control) for system migration (EBF)
entry.content:
Hello friends,

We are working on a greenfield project where ERP billing is being migrated from a legacy system to SAP S4.

As per the market regulations, actual read comes in every 6 months (or 2 months for some cases), but we still need to bill the customer on monthly basis. We are planning to implement DPC and backbill all the periods in between two actual reads. 

However, we are going to use EBF (Easy bill calculation framework) to fetch the last 6 months bills generated in the legacy system. Hence, it would create manual bill docs in the new S4 system. As DPC doesn't work on the manual bills, we are also planning to keep the historical estimated consumptions (fetched from the legacy system) in installation facts. 

How can I use the consumptions stored in the installation facts for DPC bill generation (bill category 3000)? As those are the consumption values from correction periods which are originally from the legacy system, we want DPC bill (bill category 3000) to use those values.

entry.title: Re: Is it possible to combine both IM & WM outbound deliv...
entry.content: Hi SAP, We're currently facing an issue when trying to combine a warehouse-managed (WM) outbound delivery and an inventory-managed (IM) outbound delivery into a single freight order ‚Äî both with their respective freight units. We‚Äôre using external Freight Units (planned in an external system), though we‚Äôre not sure if that‚Äôs influencing the behavior here. When we try to create a freight order that includes one Freight Unit from a WM outbound delivery and one from an IM outbound delivery, we receive the following error: "source and destination location do not match." Does this mean that IM and WM freight units can only be combined into a single freight order if they share the same stage ‚Äî meaning the same shipping point and destination? If so, that would imply we can only ship to one customer per freight order in this case. Thanks in advance for the clarification.

entry.title: 2025 SAP Digital Manufacturing Assets: IVJs, videos and blog posts
entry.content:
In this blog post, you can find all my digital assets, including Interactive Value Journeys (aka IVJs), videos and other blog posts, created in 2025. You can also check:

  • SAP Digital Manufacturing Assets: IVJs, videos and blog posts
  • 2024 SAP Digital Manufacturing Assets: IVJs, videos and blog posts

In order to better navigate it and find any specific content you might be looking for, I highly suggest you use Find (CTRL+F). Example:

IVJs - Interactive Value Journeys

  1. Get Insights by "Just Ask" for Manufacturing Data

Videos

  1. 3rd Party Supplier production reporting to SAP Digital Manufacturing via Custom POD and Public APIs
  2. Historical OEE Report based on OEE MDO and Embedded SAC within SAP Digital Manufacturing
  3. AI Agents in Manufacturing
  4. Manufacturing AI Agents: Rework AI Copilot

Blog Posts

  1. Call SAP Digital Manufacturing Production Processes via REST API
  2. (Re)using Master Operations in SAP Digital Manufacturing
  3. Relaxed Flow Routings within SAP Digital Manufacturing
  4. Nonconformance AI-based Insights in SAP Digital Manufacturing PODs
  5. SFC-Based Dispatching in Resource Orchestration
  6. SAP Digital Manufacturing 25.02 Release enhancements and new capabilities
  7. AI-based Analytics: SAP Analytics Cloud 'Just Ask' on top of SAP Digital Manufacturing data
  8. SAP Digital Manufacturing 25.05 Release enhancements and new capabilities
  9. Quantity Validation flag in Manage Routings/Recipes app
  10. How 'Relaxed Flow' flag in Manage Recipes/Routings app affects Order Release and SFC quantities
  11. SFC-Based Dispatching in REO: Granular Production Scheduling and Process Industry Support
  12. How SAP Digital Manufacturing Simplifies Tool Management
  13. Track Quality and Compliance with SAP Digital Manufacturing Reports
  14. Automating Quality Control: Rework Routing Disposition in SAP Digital Manufacturing
  15. How SAP Digital Manufacturing Supports Sustainable Manufacturing
  16. Enhance Line Monitor POD with 'Last Indicator Value' Plugin in SAP Digital Manufacturing
  17. Assembly of Unplanned (non-BOM) Materials
  18. SAP Digital Manufacturing Learning
  19. Using DM Packing Unit as Handling Unit when posting Goods Receipt to EWM
  20. Enforce required Data Collections upon Operation Complete within SAP Digital Manufacturing
  21. SAP Digital Manufacturing 25.08 Release enhancements and new capabilities
  22. Joule in SAP Digital Manufacturing

This blog post will be continuously updated, as new content is created.

Manoel Costa

entry.title: Re: Can Flexible Workflow Handle Multi-Level CMR Approval...
entry.content: We have the following requirement: CMR < 5,000 ‚Üí Approved by L2; CMR > 5,000 & < 10,000 ‚Üí Approved by L2 and L3 ; CMR > 10,000 ‚Üí Approved by L3 and L4. However, in the Fiori app, the approval steps can only be defined amount-wise at a single level, for example: CMR < 5,000 ‚Üí Approver L1; CMR > 5,000 & < 10,000 ‚Üí Approver L2; CMR > 10,000 ‚Üí Approver L3. As a result, the system behaves accordingly ‚Äî for example, for a credit memo of 7,000 EUR, it only triggers approval from L2. But our business requirement is based on the 4-eyes principle. For instance, for 7,000 EUR, the document should first be approved by L1, and then by L2. Is it possible to achieve this requirement using standard Flexible Workflow configuration, or do we need to use a BAdI or enhancement to fulfill it?

entry.title: Re: Crystal Report 2009 Vb6 and 32 architecture to migrat...
entry.content:
Hi @prakashchandra 

Thank you for your question.

First, let me confirm that your understanding is correct. You can open old reports, change data sources and fix issues during the upgrade process efficiently.

To enable you upgrade your Crystal Reports from the 2009 version to the latest Crystal Reports 2025, I recommend the following straightforward approach:

First is to open your existing 2009 reports directly in Crystal Reports 2025. The new version supports backward compatibility and will prompt you to upgrade the report format as needed.

Then update and change the data source connections if required.

Thereafter, ensure to thoroughly test your reports and address any issues or warnings that arise during the upgrade.

For multiple reports, ensure to consider tools or scripts to bulk update data source connections and ensure any add-ons or custom integrations are compatible with the new version.

Finally, ensure to always keep backups of your original reports before starting the upgrade.

I hope this provides the required details. I am happy to help if you have further questions.

Best regards

Chris

entry.title: SAP Crystal Report runtime error when published in Docker
entry.content:
hello all,

I am trying to run an executable made with Crystal Report runtime for Visual Studio Code, where we make a programmatic change to the text object. However, we would like to publish it in Docker.
But when I look at the internal logs inside the container, I am receiving an error (Docker)
MSI (s) (D8:FC) [09:25:37:438]: Product: SAP Crystal Reports runtime engine for .NET Framework (32-bit) -- Installation operation failed.
MSI (s) (D8:FC) [09:25:37:438]: Windows Installer installed the product. Product Name: SAP Crystal Reports runtime engine for .NET Framework (32-bit). Product Version: 13.0.38.5404. Product Language: 1033. Manufacturer: SAP. Installation success or error status: 1603.
Here is the code:

FROM mcr.microsoft.com/windows/servercore:ltsc2019
COPY ./System32/oledlg.dll C:\Windows\System32\oledlg.dll
COPY ./SysWOW64/oledlg.dll C:\Windows\SysWOW64\oledlg.dll
RUN powershell.exe -Command "icacls 'C:\Program Files (x86)\SAP BusinessObjects' /grant 'Everyone:(OI)(CI)F' /T"
COPY CR13SP38MSI32_0-80007712.MSI C:\CRRuntime.msi
RUN powershell.exe -Command "Start-Process msiexec.exe -ArgumentList '/i C:\CRRuntime.msi /qn /norestart ALLUSERS=1 /l*vx C:\cr_install_log.txt' -Wait"
RUN powershell.exe -Command "Remove-Item C:\CRRuntime.msi -Force"
WORKDIR /app
COPY ./publish/ .
CMD ["POC-GROUP.exe"]

The publish folder contains the build that has already been tested locally and works fine with this version of the MSI.

entry.title: In VA01, I do not want the Req Delivery Date to update to the item's first date
entry.content:
Good day,

When I create a Sales Order,  and I immediately change the Req Delivery Date (field: RV45A-KETDAT) to also update the first date of the line items (field:  RV45A-ETDAT).

The Req Delivery Date normally defaults to Today's date, but I want to prevent that the first dates on the item level do not get updated when the user creates the Sales Order and updates the Req Delivery Date immediately. This is to ensure that the materials entered, do not get seen as a future requirement and should be picked up immediately by MRP.  Otherwise I have to configure another MRP type to ignore the delivery lead time.

Any suggestions how I can do this?

The Req Delivery Date we want to use as the Delivery Date we will communicate to the customer as to when their goods will be delivered to them. However the items's first date should be today's date as MRP should immediately be triggered for replenishment.

entry.title: crossboarding- legal entity transfer
entry.content:
Is the statement about cross-boarding still accurate?

Scenarios that require a terminate and rehire process for an internal employee are not supported. For example: An internal employee changes their job from one legal entity to another (either within the same country or a different country).

entry.title: Re: Delivery document type OUTB has the wrong document ca...
entry.content:
Ok in that case, it is almost certainly due to a missing or incorrect mapping in development. Even if the configuration looks the same, the document type-to-category mapping in EWM might differ.

Check this IMG path in EWM > Interfaces ‚Üí ERP Integration ‚Üí Delivery Processing ‚Üí Map Document Types from ERP System to WM System. Make sure Delivery type OUTB is mapped to document category SPC for intra-plant STOs

Compare EWM Mapping Tables between sandbox and development. Use transaction /SCWM/MAPDLVTYP. Confirm that OUTB ‚Üí SPC mapping exists in development

entry.title: Re: In VA01, I do not want the Req Delivery Date to updat...
entry.content:
By default, when you change the header-level KETDAT, SAP tries to propagate this to the schedule lines (ETDAT). This is controlled by standard logic and ATP checks, which assume the delivery date is also the material requirement date.

Below are some workarounds

  • Use the user exit USEREXIT_MOVE_FIELD_TO_VBEP in program MV45AFZZ to override ETDAT after the user changes KETDAT. In this exit, set VBEP-EDATU (which maps to ETDAT) to SY-DATUM (today‚Äôs date). This ensures MRP sees the requirement as immediate, regardless of KETDAT. Be cautious, this logic must only trigger when the order is created or changed in a specific way, to avoid unintended overrides.
  • If you prefer a more modular approach, consider implementing BAdI SD_SALES_ITEM or ATP_CHECK. These allow finer control over schedule line behavior and ATP logic. Most importantly, avoid using MRP types to bypass lead time logic unless absolutely necessary‚Äîthis can introduce inconsistencies across planning runs

entry.title: Re: Suggestion required for implementing DPC (Dynamic Per...
entry.content:
Hi @diptarkaroy 

Thank you for your message. Let me walk you through it.

Regarding your query about using legacy system consumption values stored in installation facts for DPC bill generation (bill category 3000) in the new SAP S/4HANA system, here is the an approach to evaluate.

First, note that with proper configuration of your billing schema and rate categories, the consumptions stored in installation facts can be used as the basis for billing.

Ensure that your billing schema includes a time slice generator variant, which is designed to write consumption values to installation facts.

The rate categories assigned to the installation must have dynamic period control maintained with appropriate basic categories to use these stored consumptions.

The consumption data from your legacy system and imported via Easy Bill Framework will then serve you as input during DPC bill generation instead of meter readings.

You need to also ensure that the time slice periods align with your consumption data periods for accurate backbilling.

Please note, variants such as Update Sum in the Future may be used to adjust consumption sums and allow correct billing for historical periods.

I hope this provides the required details. I am happy to help if you have further questions.

Best regards

Chris

 

Customizing for DPC
